most cases of neuroleptic malignant syndrome; however, fatality

stituted soon after an episode.
Risk and Prognostic Factors
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a potential risk in any individual
after antipsychotic drug administration. It is not specific to any neu-
ropsychiatric diagnosis and may occur in individuals without a di-
agnosable mental disorder who receive dopamine antagonists.
Clinical, systemic, and metabolic factors associated with a height-
ened risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome include agitation,
exhaustion, dehydration, and iron deficiency. A prior episode asso-
ciated with antipsychotics has been described in 15%–20% of index
cases, suggesting underlying vulnerability in some patients; how-
